thread.title: 50 Most Iconic Oscar Red Carpet Dresses of All Time
thread.title_full: 50 Most Iconic Oscar Red Carpet Dresses of All Time

author: Lori Keong
title: 50 Most Iconic Oscar Red Carpet Dresses of All Time
text:
1 Of 50 Grace Kelly, 1955 
The queen (princess?) of red carpet elegance, Grace Kelly wearing this mint-green spaghetti strap number is everything. Getty 2 Of 50 Audrey Hepburn, 1968 
The definition of classic beauty is Audrey Hepburn wearing this modern lace-up dress with strategic cutouts (mostly because we're still dying to wear it today). Getty 3 Of 50 Natalie Wood, 1968 
When Natalie Wood stole the show in a sparkly dress, big earrings, a giant hair bow, and perfect *double* cat-eye wings. Getty 4 Of 50 Barbra Streisand, 1969 
Not one to wear anything close to traditional, here's Babs wearing a sparkly pantsuit sealed with a bow (and the perfect rounded bob to match). Getty 5 Of 50 Elizabeth Taylor, 1970 
Elizabeth Taylor wears a plunging custom violet chiffon dress designed by Edith Head to showcase a pear-shaped diamond from her husband Richard Burton. Getty 6 Of 50 Goldie Hawn, 1971 
Goldie Hawn matches her florals with a "flower child"-style spaghetti strap dress and a darling updo. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below 7 Of 50 Cher, 1973 
Cher shows off her toned abs in a sequined belly dancer get-up that led the way for midriff-baring stars like Britney Spears. 8 Of 50 Lauren Hutton, 1975 
This is how you have fun on the red carpet, as demonstrated by Lauren Hutton wearing a rainbow dress topped with a fur chubby jacket. Getty 9 Of 50 Jacqueline Bisset, 1976 
Making a case for the one-shouldered trend to come, Jacqueline Bisset wore this non-traditional striped gown with a high neck. Getty 10 Of 50 Diana Ross, 1982 
In which Diana Ross brought the glam factor with a red sparkly key-hole dress and a larger-than-life white boa.
